Package com.highsoft.highcharts.common.hichartsclasses

Class HIVariwide

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.Observable
      • com.highsoft.highcharts.core.HIFoundation
        • com.highsoft.highcharts.common.hichartsclasses.HISeries
          • com.highsoft.highcharts.common.hichartsclasses.HIVariwide
  • public class HIVariwide
extends HISeries
    A variwide series. If the type option is not specified, it is inherited from chart.type. In TypeScript the `type` option must always be set. Configuration options for the series are given in three levels: 1. Options for all series in a chart are defined in the `plotOptions.series` object. 2. Options for all variwide series are defined in `plotOptions.variwide`. 3. Options for one single series are given in `the series instance array`. ` Highcharts.chart('container', { plotOptions: { series: { // general options for all series }, variwide: { // shared options for all variwide series } }, series: [{ // specific options for this series instance type: 'variwide' }] }); `

      • getBorderRadius

      • setPointRange

        public void setPointRange​(java.lang.Number pointRange)
        The X axis range that each point is valid for. This determines the width of the column. On a categorized axis, the range will be 1 by defaults (one category unit). On linear and datetime axes, the range will be computed as the distance between the two closest data points. The defaults null means it is computed automatically, but this option can be used to override the automatic value. This option is set by defaults to 1 if data sorting is enabled.

        Try it:

         •  Set the point range to one day on a data set with one week between the points

      • getPointRange

        public java.lang.Number getPointRange()

      • setMinPointLength

        public void setMinPointLength​(java.lang.Number minPointLength)
        The minimal height for a column or width for a bar. By defaults, 0 values are not shown. To visualize a 0 (or close to zero) point, set the minimal point length to a pixel value like 3\. In stacked column charts, minPointLength might not be respected for tightly packed values.

        Try it:

         •  Zero base value
         •  Positive and negative close to zero values

      • getMinPointLength

        public java.lang.Number getMinPointLength()

      • setBorderColor

        public void setBorderColor​(HIColor borderColor)
        The color of the border surrounding each column or bar. In styled mode, the border stroke can be set with the .highcharts-point rule.

        Try it:

         •  Dark gray border

        defaults:

         #ffffff

      • getBorderColor

        public HIColor getBorderColor()

      • setCenterInCategory

        public void setCenterInCategory​(java.lang.Boolean centerInCategory)
        When true, the columns will center in the category, ignoring null or missing points. When false, space will be reserved for null or missing points.

        Try it:

         •  Center in category

      • getCenterInCategory

        public java.lang.Boolean getCenterInCategory()

      • setMaxPointWidth

        public void setMaxPointWidth​(java.lang.Number maxPointWidth)
        The maximum allowed pixel width for a column, translated to the height of a bar in a bar chart. This prevents the columns from becoming too wide when there is a small number of points in the chart.

        Try it:

         •  Limited to 50

      • getMaxPointWidth

        public java.lang.Number getMaxPointWidth()

      • setPointWidth

        public void setPointWidth​(java.lang.Number pointWidth)
        A pixel value specifying a fixed width for each column or bar point. When set to undefined, the width is calculated from the pointPadding and groupPadding. The width effects the dimension that is not based on the point value. For column series it is the hoizontal length and for bar series it is the vertical length.

        Try it:

         •  20px wide columns regardless of chart width or the amount of data points

      • getPointWidth

        public java.lang.Number getPointWidth()

      • setColorByPoint

        public void setColorByPoint​(java.lang.Boolean colorByPoint)
        When using automatic point colors pulled from the global `colors` or series-specific `plotOptions.column.colors` collections, this option determines whether the chart should receive one color per series or one color per point. In styled mode, the colors or series.colors arrays are not supported, and instead this option gives the points individual color class names on the form highcharts-color-{n}.

        Try it:

         •  False by defaults
         •  True

        defaults:

         false

      • getColorByPoint

        public java.lang.Boolean getColorByPoint()

      • setBorderWidth

        public void setBorderWidth​(java.lang.Number borderWidth)
        The width of the border surrounding each column or bar. Defaults to 1 when there is room for a border, but to 0 when the columns are so dense that a border would cover the next column. In styled mode, the stroke width can be set with the .highcharts-point rule.

        Try it:

         •  2px black border

        defaults:

         undefined

      • getBorderWidth

        public java.lang.Number getBorderWidth()

      • setGrouping

        public void setGrouping​(java.lang.Boolean grouping)
        Whether to group non-stacked columns or to let them render independent of each other. Non-grouped columns will be laid out individually and overlap each other.

        Try it:

         •  Grouping disabled

        defaults:

         true

      • getGrouping

        public java.lang.Boolean getGrouping()
